title: Army pays tribute to war hero David Steven Askin after fatal helicopter crash
text:
Army pays tribute to war hero David Steven Askin after fatal helicopter crash SAM SHERWOOD Last updated 13:56, February 15 2017 PEDRO UGARTE/AFP 
David Steven Askin pictured after a firefight with the Taliban in Afghanistan in 2011, while with the NZ SAS. 
The New Zealand Defence Force has paid tribute to a war hero killed in a helicopter crash as he fought large fires on Christchurch's Port Hills. 
David Steven Askin, known as Steve, was once injured in a Taliban shootout and had been working for Way To Go Heliservices' when he crashed near Sugarloaf on Tuesday afternoon. 
New Zealand Defence Force chief of army Major General Peter Kelly said Corporal Askin lived up to the finest traditions of the New Zealand Army. 
Askin enlisted in the army in 1998 and left in 2013, although he remained an active member of the SAS reserves. 
READ MORE: * Suspicious fires in Christchurch compound struggle 
"He was an outstanding soldier who served his country with bravery and commitment â€“ the same bravery and commitment he showed in helping his community fight these fires. 
"His performance was of the highest order and was in keeping with the finest traditions of New Zealand's military record." 
Askin was awarded the New Zealand Gallantry Star in 2014 for his service in Afghanistan, including an incident at the Intercontinental Hotel in Kabul in 2011. The Gallantry Star is New Zealand's second-highest gallantry award. 
During the incident, Askin was wounded by grenade and rifle fire, yet carried out on his mission and rescued guests from the hotel as fire broke out. 
He was cited on several other occasions for exceptional bravery during operations in Afghanistan. Ad Feedback 
"During his time in Afghanistan, Corporal Askin displayed great gallantry and leadership in the face of the enemy. He put himself in the line of fire, and put the objectives of the mission before his personal wellbeing," Kelly said. 
Askin's award was announced, without his identity being made public, in December 2014 by Minster of Defence Gerry Brownlee. 
Askin's citation for his NZ Gallantry star: 
"Serviceman D displayed outstanding gallantry on several occasions in Afghanistan in 2011. Serviceman D repeatedly faced heavy fire from determined enemies and sustained several wounds in the line of duty, while contributing to the resolution of several incidents, the protection of civilian life and undermining enemy operations. Serviceman D's performance was of the highest order and in keeping with the finest traditions of New Zealand's military record." - Stuff
